oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: McCarters Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with the McCarters (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: McCarters; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Jennifer, Lisa, and Teresa McCarter iterate how Better Be Home Soon has a different feeling from The Gift -- (00:34) Biff Collie and the McCarters discuss how they used their own band member to record a guitar track for "Up and Gone" -- (01:11) "I Haven't Got a Prayer" is discussed by the McCarters as a song they brought to Warner Brothers as the only song on the album with a orchestra in the back ground -- (02:07) The McCarters tell of how the group got their first opportunity to sing for Capitol Records and Warner Brothers though Randy Travis' producer -- (02:47) Jennifer reveals that the group had originally clog danced before they began their singing career when Jennifer was fourteen -- (03:30) Lisa discusses the structure of a show and how it is detrimental to an entertainers growth -- (04:05) The McCarters discuss Teresa's mole and how people believe Jennifer is Lisa and Teresa's mother -- (05:01) Collie and the McCarters discuss how Lisa and Teresa are twins and that Lisa is the 'runt' -- (05:20) Collie and the McCarters discuss how "Shot Full of Love" is an expression and Jennifer reflects on how they had not originally released the song on the first album -- (06:05) Collie and the McCarters discuss how the McCarters have tracks that they have not released because of their belief in timing and changing attitudes -- (07:08) Collie and the McCarters discuss how they were able to perform on Dolly Parton's show, and the McCarters reflect on their love of an unidentified tune (08:15) "Where Have You Been" is reflected upon as a wonderful song -- (08:51) "Quit While I'm Behind" is discussed as a track by Bill Casual; additionally, Casual's character is discussed by the McCarters -- (09:48) Collie inquires about writers and the McCarters vocalize how they are approached by writers -- (10:26) "If Tomorrow Never Comes" by Garth Brooks is described by the McCarters as a beautiful song that has significant pull on the McCarters -- (11:30) Collie tells a tale about Brooks desire to release "If Tomorrow Never Comes" above any other track he had done -- (11:54) The McCarters and Collie discuss Kim Patton making "Mountain Memories" specifically for the McCarters -- (13:31) Lisa reflects on her love for "Beneth Still Waters" and its writer Emmylou Harris -- (14:15) Collie and the McCarters reflect on Dolly Parton and Harris being role models while reflecting on Parton being on the Porter Wagoner Show -- (15:30) The McCarters recall traveling to California to perform on Parton's show -- (16:01) The McCarters recall working at Dollywood -- (16:19) "Better Be Home Soon" is the favorite track by each member of the McCarters and Teresa recalls hearing the song for the first time while eating lunch -- (18:57) Collie and the McCarters discuss how to pronounce "Papa Sita" and the McCarters reveal the inspiration for the song named "Mama Sita" -- (19:30) The McCarters reveal the Mexican influence on "Papa Sita" while discussing the up-tempo styling of the album -- (20:42) "Stay Within the Sound of My Voice" is described by Jennifer as a song that has a lot of meaning to her that she wants to translate a message -- (21:35) Jennifer introduces Cambell's "Stay Within the Sound of My Voice" -- (21:40) Collie and the McCarters discuss the seven siblings they all share and their father's musical contributions -- (23:00) The McCarters review their family's musical background -- (23:33) Collie tells of how Roni Stoneman would create jello in a washer and Collie and the McCarters discuss large family living -- (24:59) The process behind the demo recording of "Betcha Gonna Love Me" is described by Jennifer -- (25:56) Collie jokes about getting a reaction and has the McCarters introduce John Denver's "Back Home Again" -- (26:40) "Slow Country Dance" is reflected on by Jennifer as a waltz that they waited awhile to release -- (27:27) "Mama Knows" by Shenandoah is reflected on by Lisa as her mother's fear of losing her children -- (28:39) "I Don't Want to Cry Anymore" is joked about by Collie and the McCarters describe the feeling of hearing it live at the Blue Bird -- (29:49) The McCarters discuss their performance on the Music City Album Review away from the mic -- (29:57) The McCarters joke about becoming disc jockeys -- (30:01) Lisa McCarter radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (30:08) Teresa McCarter radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (30:17) Jennifer McCarter radio spot for the Music City Album Review
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: McCarter, Jennifer; the McCarters (Musical group)
